Tower(Defence) = Guns / Turrets + Bullets(Lots)*MissilesTower defence games often follow a formula, whereby you obey certain rules and fulfill certain criteria. Good tower defence games make this process happen invisibly and provide an experience that is both addictive and challenging, games like the seminal Defence Grid, which is considered the benchmark upon which all other Tower Defence games must be looked upon.Comparing Terrorhedron to a Tower Defence game isn't really possible, because if Tower Defence is a formula, then Terrorhedron is algebra. It is mathematical purity and brilliance, expressed in abstract form. In most Tower Defence games you have a fixed path upon which the creeps will run and try to get to your base, you may be able to mess with this path by placing towers down, or you may have fixed locations upon which to build your towers.Wait, what, I have root? ... I have root... muwahahahhaha. I HAVE ROOT!In this case you do have fixed starting locations from which to build upon, but where it departs from the norm in this case is that the tower build points are merely bases, and from there you add lego like snap connectors from which towers can grow, tree like from the root node. The game takes full advantage of this, with levels working on every single plane of a three dimensional maze, often weaving complicated, tangled paths over cubes or more complex surfaces, allowing you to maximise your opportunities if you're clever and are willing to be imaginative.That's the key bit, because you can use the snap connectors freely, the only limitation is really funds and how crazy you can get with the tower layout, want to build mighty archways with laser turrets hanging off? Go nuts. I just did for a section of the first level, and it worked beautifully. Here, you -build- the towers, step by step.Depth of field? Check. Abstract polygons? Check. Chiptunes? Check.With such an expansive canvas, the aesthetic comes as a relief, being clean and abstract, minimalist but without looking amateur, game looks slick, well rendered, and has a thumping soundtrack, and doesn't suffer any framerate issues, regardless of what mayhem is going on at the time, and the clean design of the level layout allows you to keep focussed on the action. Doing the tutorial is mandatory this time, because Terrorhedron requires you to adapt to the fact that this game will have you building corners, arches, bridges, and all kinds of things to create your own defensive setups.Enemies in this game are represented in a similarly abstract manner, simple three dimensional shapes with various colours representing their health, it keeps things simple and allows for absolutely ridiculous levels of enemies on the screen at once, when combined with the insane combinations of bases and towers, this can turn into an exceptionally busy game in a real hurry. It keeps scaling as you go, so when your carefully constructed strategy begins to falter, you may find that you have to re-engineer and expand to ever greater feats of lunacy to keep the enemies at bay.Terrorhedron University is open, enroll today.In Terrorhedron you take pretty much every principle you've learned from other Tower Defence games and then extend and amplify those concepts, turning them from basics to pure, abstracted concepts. In effect, the game takes the genre, strips away all the things that aren't needed and then refines what there is and adds a few key elements that in turn fundamentally require the player to abandon the comfort zone of "just build a tower", because it's never just a tower, not when you're perpetually adding and extending it. Tower defence is maths, Terrorhedron is the degree course.Verdict : Essential, even moreso if you are a Tower Defence fan, or a Tower Defence player looking to improve their skills in the genre.Writer and columnist for Just Reviews, where you can get similar fine reading material. Join our group, follow our curations, and throw me a like if you would like to keep up to date with our efforts!

												Terrerohedron is a tower defence game with a lot of promise and is very addictive!The concept is of a standard tower defence game but the map is in three dimensions, at first this can confuse and be disorienting but after a few games you will be spinning the map round and planning your kill zones with relative ease.I normally like TD games that allow you to maze and shape the route that the enemy takes TH does not let you do this but gets very tactical as you can build in three dimensions, you place extendable blocks and then place towers on them or more extendable blocks. This makes looking at the map in all dimensions and then thinking of how you will build a 3d kill zone in an area quite rewarding.There is not a huge amount of variety in the towers but the game does give 3-4 solid different play sets with towers you can choose from, it feels good when you enclose a complete section and then have towers that the bullets bounce back and forth to deal a crazy amount of damage.There are also some great additions that should be in all TD games, a damage counter for each tower for each round and a total so that you can see tactics that work better or towers lagging behind. A huge choice in different target priorities for every single tower, this is something that should be standard in all TD games!The game has multiplayer also and at a recent lAN 3 of us spent far longer than we would have thought trying to improve our game and win together. It is a nice addition to the game and adds a lot more hours of fun to it.The game is definitely a small indie game that is what I hope the first edition, I got it on 95% sale and paid 19 pence for the game and so my following niggles not so much pan the game but are improvements I would love to see on the TH2 and I will pay more than 19 Pence for it!The units that you try to destroy are multisided shapes and you take off sides until they have no sides left and they are destroyed. This makes it quite hard later on to identify how bad the threat is as one moving unit could end up costing you the game as it has more than 100 sides and thus all your lives. I would assume this was done for ease but even some that glow would be helpful.The camera can get very disorientating and annoying to use, there are hotkeys to mark camera points and I recommend you use them. When you build an enclosed box it is hard to select towers to build.In multiplayer even the fastest game setting is quite slow and makes it quite slow to play.There are quite a few challenging difficulties and an impossible mode, this is not for the feint hearted and one map took me nearly 3 hours before I eventually lost, unfortunately most of the time in this was trying to spend the huge amount of money I got each round and it would take 10-15 minutes to spend it all. This is a small gripe as this mode is not to played that often but a quicker way to build would be nice. Also anyone who likes Minecraft would love this mode as it turns into a TD version of it. All in all, this game is very interesting if feeling like it has a lot more to be unlocked at some point. I highly recommend getting it even if you just play some of the easier settings on a few maps, it makes you think and mixes up the tower defence area.Oh and I loved the soundtrack, one of the few games I play with music on. Make Terrerhedron 2!!!

												I've been playing TD games since the original StarCraft, and Terrorhedron is refreshingly unique amongst the genre.  This is a fun and interesting take on Tower Defense which can be very challenging.There are a variety of towers which you might expect in TD, such as single-target lasers, splashing cannons, and slow towers to name a few.  Where it gets complicated is the limited numbers and orientations of mounting points along the map.  This is when you turn to your 4-sided tetrahedrons and 6-sided cube pieces in order to expand your defensible area, which also allows you to place towers in otherwise-blind spots for coverage.Upon the last enemy's death (or when it reaches the gate and you lose lives) the round pauses for building phase.  Use this time to experiment with angles to maximize coverage of your turrets.  Any pieces you place during this time can be sold for their full cost, but once the building phase ends, all of these pieces will only be worth ~50% from then on.If you like TD and want a fresh, fun, and challenging new game to play, buy Terrorhedron.

												While this is strictly a tower defence game, the convention will only go so far as having enemies that moved in a pre-determined path and the fact that you construct towers to defeat said enemies. To succeed in this game, you must have to the mental fortitude to plan in three dimensions, as well as an abundance of creativity to maximise and extend the reach of your turrets based on limited nodes to build upon.In the first hour of play you’ll learn to construct vine like constructs to maximise your firepower, since you can only place turrets on specified nodes or extend upon them via connectors. Balancing between the reach of your foundations and your capacity to damage, you’ll glow new vines across a few strategic points, eventually connecting them all in one gigantic network. All between rounds of steadily increasing waves.The game can be mercilessly hard at higher difficulties, but it is also a rewarding experience to players that can adapt new tactics in different elevations and angles.That said, the multiplayer felt tagged on at the last minute and it suffers from sync issues when I tried it. The lack of a map editor is also a major oversight on the developer’s part, as this could have so much potential if it had workshop support; potential that was wasted simply because the devs wished to work on a newer title.If you wanted a relatively new take on the tower defence genre, you ought to give this a try. The unique visuals and catchy tunes are just icing if you happened to like the retro theme.

												This is a must have for every tower Defense Fan!  It took me a while to get used to the 3d profile and building the tower bases but the learning curve is part of the fun and challenge to most Tower D games. That is the case here as well.  A mouse is a must in my opinion.  If you are used to a track pad you could probably manage though.  You must grind a bit to unlock towers and upgrades for them,  however, they do a wonderful job of scaling it so you are grinding as you are learning and unlocking new tracks and such so It does not become a bore.  It has some kind of 3-d effect option but I have no idea how that works.  Someone more tech savvy will have to comment upon that.  The game looks great without it.  The gameplay is pretty much the same as most tower d in principle.  Different 3-d shapes move around a set 3-d track.  You set towers in set places on the track and blow 'shells' - think layers- off of different shapes until there is nothing left and the shape is obliterated.  You also have a couple choices of bases that allow you to build more than one tower in a spot.  Use slows and offensive towers to kill all the shapes without running out of lives and you will beat the track.      It also has trading cards and achieves for those that are interested.  I had bought it at the super cheap price of .24 cents but it is one of the few games that I would say is worth the full price.  I have yet to play the multiplayer modes and will amend my review to reflect that later.  Until then Game On!

												A fun an challenging 3D tower defense game.I didn't think I'd enjoy it quite as much as I do right now, but it really is quite fun to build your own constructs to place towers. Usually I prefer games where I can control the enemies path, although sometimes those kind of games get boring after a while when you know the strengths of your towers and it is simply a matter of how fast can you win instead of "can I win this at all".Since in this game the path is predefined and can't be altered by anything you do, and the path is 3-dimensional this game presents a challenge. First you have to get around in thinking in 3D when placing towers and finding your kill-zone and then you have to plan ahead of how long you can wait placing new towers in order to be able to buy the expensive but effective ones.Like most TD not all towers and upgrades are available at first, you have to do a bit of grinding to get to the good stuff. After almost 7 hours I haven't unlocked all possible upgrades yet, but it took me a while to get around this 3D thinking required, so maybe it is possible to get all the content faster.This game definitely needs a mouse to be played, the camera and controls are a bit confusing at first, but you'll get used to it after a while.PROS:+ 3D presents a challenge+ fun an really addictive game-play+ towers are built within a second (no waiting time for the tower to be completed)+ upgrading a tower can be done mid-fight without loosing precious attack-secondsCONS:- controls/camera take time to get used to- no in-game description for upgrades you haven't unlocked yet- you start out with 100 lives and loose lives whenever you let shapes escape, the amount of lives you loose depends on the kind of shape that manages to get through (still haven't figured out how many lives a certain shape is worth)Compared to other TD games it doesn't offer quite as much content but still manages to be fun for a couple of rounds. Given that it has less content (maps and towers) than other games priced at 5 bucks. I bought it on sale and I'd recommend you get this when it's around 3 bucks or less, that's the price it's definitely worth.

												80 minutes in and I have to say, this game is worth the 24c I payed. But I would be disappointed if I payed the 5USD asking price (6.24AUD for me currently). As a fun tower defense game, I can say there is nothing onscreen that isn't needed. After 5 minutes I turned off all Audio ingame as it is just a small set of annoying sounds, a stock robot voice and infuriatingly annoying music. The menu music is too loud for it's own right. But, I do enjoy this game. Tower Defense games are immensely fun, and this is no exception. I would get it while it is on sale, otherwise, I would hold your money and get another TD game. This feels like it should be in early access though, so be warned. It is rough around the edges, I am unable to get Multiplayer Co-Op working, and did I mention the horrible audio effects? Yes? Well, I will until they're changed. The gun variety. This is something I would file as neutral instead of just good or bad. It has good variety, from the stock Laser turret (essentially a short burst machine gun turret) to the EMP turret which slows down enemies (but is not worth the money, keep away as it is faulted massively). I like the plama turrets. They are very nifty for when there is a distance to cover with a lot of power needed. I tend to put them near to the entry point.The EMP turret is very bad. I thought it would be helpful but took me 10 rounds to realise the geo is only slowed down until it gets shot. Why would they chose this as a design decision? It is very strange in my opinion. But the other turrets do suffice in how well they work, just stay off of the EMP.All in all, this game is fun and a good distraction, not the best TD game. Not the most well made game in general either. It's UI is about as bland as the UI from Bad Rats. And we all know how terrible that game was, dont we...If you have some money to spare from maybe some steam trading cards, go for it, it's worth a buy then. But for the $5 marking price I personally wouldn't go for it. There are plenty of other TD games out there for such a low price with much higher content and a lot more well made than this one. 												A cheap standard Tower Defence game which gives value for money.There's not a huge amount of content in Terrorhedron but enough to give you a decent amount of game time.It has 6 maps which are in 3D letting the tracks twist and bend around.There's a limited amount of build locations on the maps however you can expand from them with extension blocks to have as many towers as you can buy.. or as many as your computer can handle.You have several turrets which you can place on them however I found myself using the same tactic throughout all the levels which left some of them redundant, i felt like more could have been done to make the others more useful and give you more ways of passing the waves of attack.One of the odd things that I didn’t like when I first started playing was how the towers unlocked, what you start with weren’t good enough and meant failing, once unlocked they stayed unlocked so it was a little pointless to go through.There’s several difficulty settings which give more waves of attacks, plenty of hours can be put into completing the game but I really do wish there were more to it.Unlike nearly all Tower Defence games, Multiplayer Co-op is available and for up to 8 people.Anyone into Tower Defence should enjoy it and Terrorhedron goes on sale quite frequently for a high discount so it’s definitely worth a shot if you pick it up on sale however it really isn’t much at full price for the time you get out it.

Posted: July 21, 2015
												The game lacks polish.For example, the game features an unlock system, where you have to play the game more before you unlock the different tower types.  On the one hand, I suppose this system is intended to ease players into the game.  I would have preferred having everything to toy around with at the beginning; right now I'm playing the game just to unlock the types before I really start playing around with it.However, the isn't implemented into the UI well.  Locked tower types are greyed out before you've unlocked them.  The problem is that all unlocked towers stay highlighted, even when you don't have enough money to buy them.  I frequently try to buy towers when I don't have enough money, assume that I bought them, and look back to see they're not there.  There's no "you can't buy this" error noise, no flashing X over the button... just nothing.It would have been nice to have the prices of the towers shown above the icons rather than only display on hovering over the icon.  It would also be nice to have your total money shown on the bottom of the screen next to the "buy" icons so that you can see more easily how much money you have left.Also, when placing the towers, hovering over a tower placement spot should ghost the tower in and show its range.  I keep placing towers and expecting them to have their range 10-15% bigger.  It keeps feeling like tower placement spots *should* just reach a little bit longer, but they fall short fairly often.Additionally, towers can't shoot at anything below their placement plane.  I was expecting the towers to be able to shoot downward within a ~30 degree angle; most tower placement spots are absolutely useless because they can't shoot at ANYTHING below the horizontal plane they're placed in....and there's no resolution options, or framerate options.  And there's no options to turn up the shadow quality.  And there's no button in the pause screen to restart the level.  There really also could have been a way to go back to the beginning of the last wave....and there's no way to change the controls.  And the game should zoom in more for each click of the scroll wheel.  And the game should zoom in toward where the mouse is focused on the screen.  And I have a brother who only plays games with controller support.I was wondering if this game was actually released or not.  A bunch of these ought to have been fixed in an Early Access phase.  But the game has been out for a year, and it's apparently not getting any better than this.Just get Defense Grid instead.

												TerrorhedronTerrorhedron is an amazing 3D tower defence game.  Its soundtrack is cool and everything else about the game is also cool.  Basically, there is a track made out of cubes and on it there are many circle shaped platforms.  These platforms can have weapons put on them.  The weapons are all turrets.  Some examples of these weapons are Laser Turrets, EMP Turrets and Photon Pulse Turrets.  These turrets can be upgraded to a maximum of level three (they start off at level one).  Also, when you unlock a new turret or upgrade you usually get a Steam achievement.  There are forty seven achievements in total for the game and twenty one of them come from unlocking turrets and their upgrades.  This is excluding the two achievements for unlocking the four and six face turret platforms.  The rest of the achievements are unlocked when you complete different levels at various difficulties.When I was playing the game, I realised that the soundtrack was really good.  Since the rest of the game was also brilliant I paid no attention to the soundtrack until I went back to the menu screen.  That gave me an idea.  They should make a DLC for the soundtrack, why not.  Anyway, I really enjoyed this game because it involves strategy and because it is a 3D tower defence.  It has been made really well and the tutorial teaches you what you mainly need to know to play.  Also, as you continue the game you will discover a few secrets.I would rate this game 90/100 because of the graphics, the levels and because of the fact that you get to annihilate and obliterate geometrical shapes.  Some things it could improve on is a cooler design theme in the menu and and cooler design theme in the turret selection that is at the bottom of the screen when you are in a level.  Overall, I enjoyed the game a lot and it is definitely worth the minuscule price (which I think should be higher as the game is of really high quality).  Don't forget there is a co-op and multiplayer section in the game so don't stop when you have had enough of single player.  Great game.

												Game is poop. The guys you shoot are different colored triangles and your towers are rather bland as well. No story or anything. Nobody is on multiplayer. 6 different maps to play for single player and thats it. Pretty bare features. The ideas of them moving around these strange shapes is kind of cool in concept, but its actually super annoying because the camera control is probably the worst I've ever seen in a game. One mouse you click and hold and can move side to side, the other rotates, then you use the the WASD to zoom, or the mouse wheel, but either way takes too long to be helpful. You constantly forget which mouse button does which, which isnt good when you have to follow the guys around this winding flipping track, you end up more annoyed than anything else. There are only a few preset areas you can build, and the targetable areas make no sense. In the first level I built a tower on top of a ledge, overlooking the path. But the tower couldnt hip them because I couldn't see from my view but they went up the wall and flipper under. So it was a waste and early so I lost. Why even have that preset area something if it cant shoot. You spend half the time flipping around navigating the map to try and find placeable spots but you never are sure if they will be effective or hit the path, because of some dumb rule they made where you can shoot sideways, and up, but no down (??). I place another turret in a preset spot because i wanted to kill them but it was next to a path where they go up and down and got instantly blocked by them going down. It just makes it frustrating rather than inventive. There are also no-rebindable controls in the game. The fact this type of strange path game on weird geometry shapes exists would be ok, but the terrible camera and controls make it 10x worse. I would lose because if anything got past I would get lost trying to maneuver the camera around to find them on their random♥♥♥♥♥path and by then it would be too late. I also couldn't ever tell if the placeable turret would work because of the angle they would be at compared to the path, so you can't really react and fix the problem of them getting past. There is this strange and confusing 4-6 way branching thing you can place that you can then place the tower on one of the branches, I think effectively switching its direction, but it costs money and you only see how it works once on a basic tutorial level. It would have been better if they didn't need that and make the turrets fire properly, like placing them upside down they can fire to the side and below. 4.5/10. Not impressed. 												As a fan of the Tower Defense Genre I believe this game to be far too complicated in terms of defense layout creation. You may begin construction of your defenses upon developer chosen insert points and nowhere else. On these points you may construct either a defense tower or install a triple adaptor and/or extension in order to set up defenses for parts of the level which do not have these insert points. These adaptors can be stacked as much as you like...I have no quarrel with unlimited creativity but when it stems up, down, left and right with unlimited avenues it begins to lose its charm quite quickly as you have so much option but very little drive to do so. There is no game atmosphere to give you any reason to play...Infinite ways of stemming out from insert points creates a game based on extreme patience and testing; something I nor most of my friends have.Also, the theme of this game is very dull with simplistic cube styled levels, mostly unimaginative towers and enemies that are just difference shapes and colours to represent how much damage they can take as they travel through the maze... No, you cannot plan out the maze, only the defenses.This game just gets boring extremely quickly and doesn't allow you to do a simple restart even if you DO manage to maintain focus upon this game.If the theme was changed and each tower felt like it provided a more unique and useful design then this concept could become an okay game. The problem really is that this game is just an unimaginative geometrical bore which will most likely find you quitting not because you failed, but because you failed to get to the point of failure.This is boring and dull but could be made better with the existence of some imaginative graphics and more interesting concepts.This game I would rate a 35/100 due to its boring gameplay, unimaginative style, Lack of polish and the biggest no no of tower defense games: Leaving out a RESTART LEVEL button.There are better games out there which will provide more fun and charm, including veteran TD players.

												I wasn't really sold on the game until I had played through and failed, then took a closer look at the opening cinematic, and it dawned on me: This isn't just a tower defense game, this is taking control of an organic mutating monster hiding in the guise of a clean, isometric world.From the beginning, all three dimensions are brilliantly used, with the travel path going over, under, and all around the map, leaving you to find the nooks and crannies to place you units, but it seems lacking and some of the very limited build spots are useless. The game truly comes alive as soon as you start using the trees to build off in dizzying directions. No place to put a unit? Cobble an insane hodgepodge of trees around to wherever you want it. Forget the ground, hang a dozen turrets right over the path and make them walk the gauntlet. With enough cleverness and cash you could win the game from a single build spot. I strongly prefer to use the 4-way trees instead of the 6-way for the surprising element of organic chaos they introduce.No game will ever be "optimal" and no two games will ever feel the same, unless you consciously force it. Sell-back is cheap to encourage continuous urban renewal of your garden; in fact, the most basic turret sells-back for the same price at level 1, so you can stick 'em all over to figure out what has coverage and what needs more.The main downsides are that the camera controls suck (left and right click are reversed to my intuition, zoom is too slow, and grabbing hold of things to rotate is incredibly random), and there's no endless mode. I also wish it'd show you the firing arc a unit will have BEFORE you buy it. Despite being "done" I hope they revisit it someday. You'll start getting used to the controls, but you'll stop cursing them when you get sucked into how insanely involved it gets.Terrorhedron is some of the most fun I've had with a defense game in years. Once it clicked, it really, really clicked.

The game truly comes alive as soon as you start using the trees to build off in dizzying directions. No place to put a unit? Cobble an insane hodgepodge of trees around to wherever you want it. Forget the ground, hang a dozen turrets right over the path and make them walk the gauntlet. With enough cleverness and cash you could win the game from a single build spot. I strongly prefer to use the 4-way trees instead of the 6-way for the surprising element of organic chaos they introduce.No game will ever be "optimal" and no two games will ever feel the same, unless you consciously force it. Sell-back is cheap to encourage continuous urban renewal of your garden; in fact, the most basic turret sells-back for the same price at level 1, so you can stick 'em all over to figure out what has coverage and what needs more.The main downsides are that the camera controls suck (left and right click are reversed to my intuition, zoom is too slow, and grabbing hold of things to rotate is incredibly random), and there's no endless mode. I also wish it'd show you the firing arc a unit will have BEFORE you buy it. Despite being "done" I hope they revisit it someday. You'll start getting used to the controls, but you'll stop cursing them when you get sucked into how insanely involved it gets.Terrorhedron is some of the most fun I've had with a defense game in years. 												Combining resource management with tower defense and math, Terrorhedron does well to offer a great challenge as you place several types of turrets in crazy positions to compensate for their 180* firing radius.Just note that this game can be a bit like Morrowind. You may screw up and fail a few times before you get a hang of it and start kicking orb hiney. Just know where to place your turrets so you can get the full effect of their firepower. It may take a bit of trial and error, but anyone with decent knowledge of geometry should get the hang of it in no time.Unfortunately, there are only about eight turrets in the game, each with only a max level of 3. There are also only six maps available. And while each of them are challenging, they can get a bit too easy to memorize once you start getting better. Some DLC maps and turrets would be a nice addition. There is also an experience system for unlocking the maps, turrets, and turret upgrades. The only thing I hate about this game's experience system is that there is no level cap. Once you hit level 30, you unlock everything, which makes gaining any more EXP pointless because unlocking things is the only purpose it serves.Overall, I'd give Terrorhedron an 8/10. Better bought when it's on sale, since it's $0.49 when on sale

												WOW.  This game's awesome.  Concept's the same as all other TD games, the little creeps that you have to kill travel on a set path, and you have several fixed tower positions.  But the awesome thing is that you're able to build base blocks with MORE tower spots on them.  So let's say on a map, you've got just one tower spot to build on.  You could put a cube-shaped base block on that spot, giving you five more build spots on that block (top and the 4 sides).  On top of that cube, you could put ANOTHER cube-shaped base block, so now you've got 8 sides and 1 top build spot.  So far, I've seen the cube-shaped base block and a triangle-shaped base block, not sure if there are more to come, but with just these two, the possibilities are endless.The turrets, I have yet to get the hang of.  Sometimes I'll place a turret in a spot and think it's gonna fire and be very effective, but it just won't function at all.  But, if you build to check out the turret's firing distance/directions, and then sell BEFORE you start the round, the tower/baseblock sells for full price.  You're always getting XP and unlocking stuff, too, so losing doesn't even feel terrible.  Feels almost like I'm MORE encouraged to play as I lose, making mistakes is rewarding me with more skill.  I dunno, I love it so far. There's maybe a half hour learning curve.  The camera's tough to get the hang of at first, the UI's really barebones, and I'm not able to find a controls section (probably isn't one), but if it's possible to rotate the base blocks, I definitely want to know how.  Also turned the music off -immediately- because no sir.  Developers, if you're reading this, I can compose a far better soundtrack for you, or just let you use an instrumental album I've already written/recorded.I just can't stress enough how great the gameplay is.  Anything in this review that even sounds remotely like a drawback, it's a minor gripe that I honestly don't care about.  Bells and whistles can go to hell.  The strategy in this game is second to none.8.5/10.  Maybe a 9.  I'd give it a 10 if it came with flashier graphics (I'm picturing RUSH meets Defense Grid 2), the ability to rotate base blocks, an easier camera, and a pause button.  Took me 20 minutes to know I'll be playing this game for years to come.  Basic UI, basic graphics, and GENIUS, spectacular, limitless gameplay.
